body: Was this what was causing the UI issues on Windows and tmux with writing on the first line?
I don't believe so... but it could be. I'll test.
It was not, by the way.

body: This could cause problems if we have old, left-over files in $BIN/Debug/dnxcore50 and they over-write newly built files in $BIN.

body:
Yes it would, in which case you'd want to `rm -rf bin`.

The latest dotnet-nightly packages have removed the need for this work-around, so we should remove it soon.

body:
Or just rm –rf $BIN/Debug every time we build.

I don’t see any Modules/SnapIn related stuff in this PR?

From: Andy Schwartzmeyer [mailto:notifications@github.com]
Sent: Monday, February 1, 2016 10:34 AM
To: PowerShell/PowerShell-Linux PowerShell-Linux@noreply.github.com
Cc: George Fleming (Insight Global) v-geflem@microsoft.com
Subject: Re: [PowerShell-Linux] Use Modules instead of SnapIns (#466)

In build.ps1https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell-Linux/pull/466#discussion_r51459097:

>  cd ../..
> 
>  # Publish PowerShell
> 
>  cd src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host
> 
>  dotnet publish --framework dnxcore50 --output $BIN
> 
>  # Temporary fix for dotnet publish
> 
> -cp $BIN/Debug/dnxcore50/\* $BIN
> 
> +if (Test-Path $BIN/Debug/dnxcore50) { cp $BIN/Debug/dnxcore50/\* $BIN }

Yes it would, in which case you'd want to rm -rf bin.

The latest dotnet-nightly packages have removed the need for this work-around, so we should remove it soon.

—
Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell-Linux/pull/466/files#r51459097.

 # Publish PowerShell

 dotnet publish --framework dnxcore50 --output $BIN
 # Temporary fix for dotnet publish
-cp $BIN/Debug/dnxcore50/* $BIN
+if (Test-Path $BIN/Debug/dnxcore50) { cp $BIN/Debug/dnxcore50/* $BIN }
body:
You could add `rm -rf bin` to whatever alias you use to run the build script, but I don't think it should be part of `build.sh` because then we'd lose the ability to do incremental recompilation.

Please see the linked PR in this PR's description.

!hasNext check is unnecessary?

On Windows, "powershell -help me" works.
I would say that's a quirk of their implementation, our usage doesn't permit arguments to `--help`. We certainly could enable that too. Think we should?
In general I don't think --help must be by itself.  I tried a few other commands, and they seem to work also.  E.g. "emacs --help me", "less -help me" all work.
All righty, will amend. Thanks!

body:
This looks like a reimplementation of the "managed" C++ code of the MMIN in C#, which is exactly what we need. Unfortunately, I have little knowledge of this code, and so am not going to be a very good reviewer.

@fearthecowboy Can you take a look at this? If we get all of MMIN ported correctly, we theoretically would not need the managed C++ any more. I think.
